title: How did the Diamondbacks make the World Series?
text:
The World Series ended over a week ago with the Texas Rangers convincingly beating the Arizona Diamondbacks four games to one. Was anyone expecting that these would be the last two teams playing in November? No, not really.
Rebuilding. That was the name of the game for these two teams and arguably the reason they were even in the World Series. Just two seasons ago, in 2021, the Rangers lost 102 games. Last season, was a little bit better with only losing 94. The Diamondbacks, on the other hand, lost a startling 110 games in the 2021 season and last season they improved by only losing 88 games. These were teams that people didn’t think would win the World Series anytime soon.
Let’s take a look at how the season went for these two teams and the rest of the league.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(ggalt)
library(ggtext)
library(patchwork)

stats <- read_csv("baseballregularseason.csv")

AL <- stats |>
  group_by(Team, League) |> 
  summarise(
    BaseHits = sum(H), 
    Strikeouts = sum(SO)) |>
  filter(League == "AL")

NL <- stats |>
  group_by(Team, League) |> 
  summarise(
    BaseHits = sum(H), 
    Strikeouts = sum(SO)) |>
  filter(League == "NL")

bar1 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=AL, 
    aes(y=reorder(Team, BaseHits), x=BaseHits, xend=Strikeouts),
    size = 3,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
 
   labs(
        x = "Number of Base Hits & Strikeouts",
    y = "American League"
  ) +
  theme_minimal()

bar2 <- ggplot() + 
  geom_dumbbell(
    data=NL, 
    aes(y=reorder(Team, BaseHits), x=BaseHits, xend=Strikeouts),
    size = 3,
    colour = "grey",
    colour_x = "green",
    colour_xend = "red") +
  labs(
      caption = "Source: MLB.com | By Addi Bickford",
       x = "Number of Base Hits & Strikeouts",
       y = "National League"
  ) + 
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(face= "bold", size = 12),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  ) 

bar1 + bar2  +
  plot_annotation(
    title="Base Hits vs Strikeouts", 
    subtitle = "You always want more base hits than strikeouts. Ideally, you want <span style = 'color:green;'>Base Hits</span> on the right and <span style = 'color:red;'>Strikeouts</span> on the left. If that isn't the case for your team. How was your season this year?"
  ) & theme(
    plot.subtitle = element_textbox_simple(size = 9),
    plot.title = element_text(face= "bold"),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  ) 





The Rangers were number one in the American League at the end of the regular season having more base hits than strikeouts. In contrast, the Diamondbacks finished 10th in the National League but, fortunately, they did finish with more base hits than strikeouts as well.
How about home runs? How did that turn out for all the teams? You have the Braves pair of Acuna and Olson, the Dodgers duo of Freeman and Betts, and Angels All-Star Ohtani. No explanation is necessary.


Code
library(tidyverse)
library(patchwork)

ALtotals <- stats |> 
  filter(League == "AL") |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarize(
    TotalHomeRuns = sum(HR),
  )

NLtotals <- stats |> 
  filter(League == "NL") |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarize(
    TotalHomeRuns = sum(HR),
  )

tx <- ALtotals |> filter(Team == "Texas Rangers")
az <- NLtotals |> filter(Team == "Arizona Diamondbacks")
ALbar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=ALtotals, aes(x=reorder(Team, TotalHomeRuns), weight=TotalHomeRuns), fill="darkgrey") + 
  geom_bar(data=tx, aes(x=reorder(Team, TotalHomeRuns), weight=TotalHomeRuns), fill="#C0111F") + 
  coord_flip() + 
  labs(
    x="American League", 
    y="Home Runs"
    ) + 
  theme_minimal() 

NLbar <- ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=NLtotals, aes(x=reorder(Team, TotalHomeRuns), weight=TotalHomeRuns), fill="darkgrey") +
  geom_bar(data=az, aes(x=reorder(Team, TotalHomeRuns), weight=TotalHomeRuns), fill="#30CED8") + 
  coord_flip() +  
  labs(
    x="National League", 
    y="Home Runs") + 
  theme_minimal()

ALbar + NLbar  + 
  plot_annotation(
    title = "Which Team Hit the Most Home Runs?",
    subtitle = "Arizona is living proof that you don't have to just be a home-run hitting team to make it to the World Series.",
    caption = "Source: MLB.com | By Addi Bickford"
  ) & 
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank()
  )





Would you look at that? The Rangers are ranked first in the American League yet again. No surprise when you have players like Corey Seager and Adolis Garcia. However, the Diamondbacks finished 11th in the National League.
Okay, so maybe the Diamondbacks aren’t power hitters. That’s fine. They probably lean more on extra-base hits like doubles & triples.


Code
library(tidyverse)

extrabasehits <- read_csv("extrabasehits.csv")

xbasehits<- extrabasehits |> 
  group_by(Team) |> 
  summarise(
    Doubles = sum(`2B`),
    Triples = sum(`3B`),
    Homeruns = sum(HR))

 xbh <- xbasehits |> 
  pivot_longer(
    cols=-Team, 
    names_to="Type",
    values_to="Total")
ggplot() + 
  geom_bar(data=xbh, aes(x=reorder(Team, Total), weight=Total, fill=Type)) + 
  coord_flip() + 
  scale_fill_manual(values=c("#002D72", "#D50032", "black")) +
  
  labs(
    x="Team", 
    y="Number of Extra Base Hits", 
    title="Extra Base Hits By Teams This Season",
    subtitle="Home runs are always great, but doubles and triples can greatly impact a game.", 
    caption="Source: MLB.com | By Addi Bickford"
    ) + 
  
  theme_minimal() &
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    axis.title = element_text(size = 8), 
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size=10), 
    panel.grid.minor = element_blank(),
    plot.title.position = "plot"
  )





Per usual, the Rangers finished near the top while the Diamondbacks finished in the bottom half of the entire league yet again.
So how did the Arizona Diamondbacks make it to the World Series when their regular season was average?
The only answer that makes sense is they got hot at the right time and won when they needed to. Even though the Rangers won it all, it’s still a significant accomplishment for the Diamondbacks to make it when no one else thought they would.
